etymologies: 1920s; earliest use found in La France. From French élinvar, shortened from élasticité invariable invariable elasticity, with reference to the salient property of the alloy

definitions: Any of a series of alloys, consisting typically of iron and nickel with some chromium, which have a constant modulus of elasticity over a wide temperature range.

notes.text: Such alloys are used especially to make springs for mechanical timepieces, their mechanical properties being little affected by changes in ambient temperature.
